author: dmeti

description.text:
This is a fan I built to move the air around my potted plants, which have been supporting a burgeoning population of thrips, whiteflies, aphids, or some other tiny winged pests. Much like some of the larger non-chemical insect traps out there, this moves air through a mesh screen (from a 2.5" diameter mesh tea ball) that traps the insects in a breeze they can't fly free from. Then, if they stay there long enough, they die.
The bottom base pops off to allow you to empty the fan of their little carcasses. If you want to hasten them along, you can add water or some scented oil that they can drown in.
I ran the first version overnight and it trapped about fifty of the little suckers. It also makes a nice desk fan; the exit spout is orientable, so you can direct the breeze away from the intake, and it has a fun form that looks nice on a desk. I printed this one in red but I plan to make the ones for my windowsills in green so it blends into the foliage better. Alternatively, if you're not trying to kill bugs, you can fill the tea ball half-full with potpourri to scent the air, or add liquid potpourri to the base. If you use any of that serious air freshener juice, put it in a small tin inside the base because that stuff melts plastic. Please don't ask me how I know this.

Order a USB ventilation fan and tea ball:
http://www.amazon.com/Thermaltake-Mobile-Fan-External-Cooling/dp/B00080G0BK
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0000DE7P1/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8 Print and deraft the three parts. Tap the three holes in the exit spout to 4-40, and thread in three 4-40 screws. Drop the tea ball into the socket in the intake, and assemble the spout to the intake to sandwich the flange of the tea ball (if you make multiples, you might be able to use just half of the tea ball, allowing you to buy half as many tea balls). Tighten down the three screws until they drop into the spin groove and the spout spins with some resistance but won't come off.
Disassemble the fan,by un-nutting the four perimeter screws. Take a grille, the fan, and the speed control subassembly, and fit them into the square socket in the intake, with the spider in the fan facing in. Drop the four screws through the stack, and insert the nuts into the hexagonal sockets in the back. Tighten.
Pop the base cap on, and set the fan down on it. Plug it in to your nearest USB socket, and fire it up. Adjust the flow direction to your liking by rotating the exit spout.

comments.text: Haha, I can confirm how effective this kind of arrangement is.  I had a square fan sitting by my window, by itself, to try and drive a little airflow this summer.  It turned out to be the bug-equivalent of a wind-farm hazard.

comments.text: Sorry for the year-plus delay.  I brought in some pepper plants this fall to overwinter them, so I set up a few of these to keep air moving over the leaves.  I posted the requested picture of a few week's worth of carnage.  I believe the effectiveness is highly dependent on how aggressive an infestation you have.  In this case, it seems to be fairly effective at keeping the insect population down... although it's a complex function indoors since the little bastards are no doubt breeding in my compost pail by the sink...

comments.text:
It's designed to blow the critters into the screen, where they die a horrible death and then their carcasses tumble into the detachable cup below. So... airflow is everything. Fan blows in, air comes out the spout.
I did run one in green after this, but that was just so it would blend into the foliage better.

author: jasim

description.text:
Yet another take on a printrbot x axis extension.
I wanted to reuse the original plate, but still be able to use 400mm rods so later extensions are possible.

Print the left endstop and the two plate holder parts.
Replace the original rods and belt with longer ones.
Attach the endstop to the end of the rods with strips.
Similarly, attach the two plateholdes to a rod each with strips, and attach them to eachother with another strip. The head of the strip should point down, as this is what will hit the x-axis endstop.
Attach the plate to the plateholders with the original screws.
This extends the build area to 130x100.
You can now print the right endstop and replace the original with this (similarly to the left endstop), which will extend the area to 150x100.

The printer then moves to start a new base in the center, instead of having one continuously connected base, and the filament ends up getting balled up around the extruder. title: UK BS1363 Electrical Socket Shutter Prong & Holder

description.text:
Multipurpose prong to insert 2-pin European type plugs into UK BS1363 type sockets with (safety) shutters.  
I have a mixture in the house, some have "simple" shutters that can be opened by depressing the pin in the Earth port, others, like the one featured, require some jigging on the Live (line) and Neutral ports.  
This prong works for BOTH types. For the "simple" shutter type, use the prong at the end of the handle, for the other "annoying" type, simply insert the dual prongs, roll it to one side, insert one side of the 2-pin plug, remove the prong fully, insert other side of the plug, voila!   
Design includes a holder that you can paste to the side of the socket with double-sided tape.

title: customizable bridges for wooden train track, incl duplo

description.text:
This is a customizable adapter between the wooden train track (BRIO) and DUPLO constructions. It is customizable, you can tweak it at the below link to match your requirements and download a printable STL. UPDATE:
many new parameters introduced. The adapter can now serve as a ramp, bending flat wooden train into an upward sloping or downward sloping. For long slopes, there's also a tilted middlepiece.
See instructions. Link:
http://beta.gigmade.com/2015/03/duplo-brio-adapter/ UPDATE:
the sloped pieces work fine, see pic. From initial playing, it's probably best to choose a slope around 30%. The piece that converts the flat into raising slope could be chosen slightly longer than the default, to avoid trains touching the floor.
Customize

These parameters can be used to configure your own duplo brio adapter on its [link] (http://beta.gigmade.com/2015/03/duplo-brio-adapter/):
  • brio track length: the length of the wooden train track piece
  • brio slope (%): percent train slope (the wooden traintrack standard seems to be 40%)
    --> make that positive or negative! (Slope 0 for a simple straight.)
  • slope ends?: whether the slope transitions into horizontal, or just keeps going.
  • reverse pins?: exchange male and female train pins
  • duplo length in units/width in units/height in units: duplo size. e.g. 4, 2, 1 for a duplo with 4x2 pins and standard height
  • transfer to duplo: add a middlepiece between duplo and track piece for printability
  • with duplo: whether to attach a duplo on the bottom or not. (A slope start piece will not need the attach duplo)
    • Examples

Using the default parameters, change
  • keep all defaults, for an end ramp that transitions to flat (see endramp.stl)
  • slope ends? = no, for a bridge that keeps raising (midramp.stl)
  • "brio slope = 40, reverse pins = yes, transfer to duplo = no, with duplo* = no, for the matching piece that starts the raise (startramp.stl)

author: tsgreen

description.text:
Here you can find our 3D-printable hand for the PARLOMA (www.parloma.com) project. Developed starting from InMoov project (www.inmoov.fr). With respect to InMoov's left hand, we add abduction/adduction joints to thumb, index and middle fingers, and redesign the palm. Now flexion/extension DoF is controlled with a tendon (flexion) and a spring (extension) inserted in the finger itself. Moreover, motion transmission has been improved introducing nylon sheaths to reduce friction and to have a greater flexibility in the positioning of the actuators and consequently a greater freedom in the design. Soon we will add more control code and instruction. Videos
===
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GS6_jwnSgWA
http://youtu.be/vairRq1zJEU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EJ5-uBt7rHs Control Software
======
http://github.com/parloma/parloma_hand UPDATES

    The hand is still in beta phase, CADs may change!
    We are working hard to release final version of the hand as soon as possible. Contributors

description.text: S/O to MM3305 3D Printing and Additive Manufacturing at the University of Minnesota!
My wife is making cakes for her sister's wedding, and wanted something nice for the Bride and Groom stamp, so I made these

Tuben Knecht - Tubes servant  
hier ein etwas ungewöhnlicher Gebrauchsgegenstand. Meist werden die heutigen Tuben aus Kunststoff hergestellt und man kann sie auf den Kopf stellen, was sehr praktisch ist. Aber es gibt immer noch Tuben, die aus Metal sind. Sehr unansehnlich werden diese dann, wenn der Inhalt zur Hälfte herausgepresst wurde. Auch ist das Hinstellen auf den Kopf oft nicht möglich. Um ein schönes Bad zu gestalten, ist dieses kleine Hilfsmitte sehr geeignet. Möglich ist auch eine farbliche Anpassung fürs Bad oder als Warnung für den Inhalt (Medikamente).  
Der Gegenstand wurde mit FreeCAD erstellt  
Tubes servant  
here is a little unusual commodity. Most today's tubes are made of plastic and you can put them on the head, which is very convenient. But there are still tubes that are made of metal. These will then be very unattractive, if the content has been pressed halfway. Even putting down on the head is often not possible. To make a nice bathroom, this small auxiliary center is very suitable. It is also a color match for the bathroom or as a warning for the content (drugs).          
The item was created with FreeCAD          
(Translated by Google)

I slide these rings onto the battery contacts of lipos with JST connectors after charging them. Only charged batteries have charge markers. The rings physically block the contacts and have to be removed before the batteries can be used so it is impossible to forget to remove the charge markers. This is a simple system for keeping track of which batteries need to be charged after a trip to the field. I am thinking of printing rings in a different color and use these to mark storage charged batteries. I have not started doing so yet, but it seems like a good idea. The markers are both quick and easy to print. The rings in the images are printed with 0.3 layer height. The tolerances are tight so you might have to increase or decrease the print size a few percent depending on your particular printer and setup. I have made another variant for XT60 connectors than can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:700056 And yet another for HXT4mm connectors can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:701727
Project for Foundation Year MICA

description.text:
The cdr file here is preview only, for editable format, please download via https://github.com/HKCOTA/TinyBoy Contains CAD files (Inventor format) and Laser cutting file (corel draw format) Project started since 2013
http://www.slideshare.net/noaizumi1/ss-25011267 What is TinyBoy? TinyBoy - Open Design 3D Printer for Student and kids
A small , easy to build , affordable machine TinyBoy is an open design 3D printer. The size is just 15 x 15 x 21cm , even smaller than most of the 2D paper printer. Therefore , it fit for regular computer desk. The design aims as an entry-level machine for student and newbie to learn 3D modeling technology and train for creative thinking. TinyBoy Website:
http://www.tinyboy3dp.net/ FaceBook:
https://www.facebook.com/tinyboy3dp Supporting Organisation: Hong Kong Creative Open Technology Association (HKCOTA)
Opensource Hong Kong (OSHK)
Hong Kong Linux User Group (HKLUG) Less is more The maximum size of printed object is 8 x 8 x 8cm , which is relatively small than many other 3D printer. However, it is already large enough for making things like figure and toy. The gain from the trade off is the cost down of material and maintenance. Take out components for making large printed object , the design become simple and lean. The core material is acrylic sheet and connected by metal screw. Therefore , the cost of material and building can be minimized. Easy to build / Learning by making The process of making has the opportunity to transform education by inviting students to be something other than consumers of education. They can be maker of anything , moving from being directed to self-directed through the process. Tinyboy is designed for easy to build. The assemble from kit can be done by just using a screw driver. We wish student can make their own machine. Then they become a pioneer whose may make another one for other people. So that the use of 3D printer can be spread out to more student. The case of TinyBoy uses acrylic plane as the main material. Individual parts can be made by using cutter laser. Therefore, the manufacturing process is easy once you have a laser cutter. In fact , the price of an A5 laser cutter can be as cheap as USD $400. That make the cost of small amount production be reasonably low. Specification Size: 15cm(W) x 15cm(D) x 22cm(H) (excl. filament holder)
Printed size : 8cm x 8cm x 8cm
1.75mm filament / 0.4mm hotend Contributors Parker Leung (Designer)
Wan Leung Wong
Haggen So
Henry Law
TC Liu
Ben Lau (Honourable)

This is a hand powered fan. It spins using a finger tapping motion. It was created in Tinkercad and printed in ABS on a Flashforge Creator Pro 3D Printer. The fins are only small so it doesn't move a huge amount of air. But it's a fun desk toy and can produce a little bit of cooling. I'm hoping to create a V2 in the future with larger fins and gears to spin the fan even faster. Sample & Install video: http://youtu.be/Iq9BotNDr5g The idea of a tapping motion to spin the fan is based on wooden fans created by Youtube user noho91

To print everything at once, download All_Parts_Single_Print.stl  
Otherwise you can download the individual parts. Just remember to print 8 pieces of Wing Part.stl  
Printed without rafts but with supports turned on.   
All of the pieces can actually be printed without supports except the fan blades and the hub.

title: Custom case for CNC DRO panel

description.text:
Custom case for DRO board mounted behind 1.5mm aluminium plate.  
The image of the DRO is a 5 axis model. This is for a 4 axis version of the same type.

Orientate parts for best printing - the main case part needs to be printed face down. 1 of each file.  
Print all parts  
On the large buttons, remove the thin webbing so each button can move independantly. This webbing is to aid in printing and sticking to bed.  
Place in buttons in correct orientations into correct holes.  
Heat bond or glue the block on large buttons into case.  
Place PCB into metal frame and then place on case. Screw through PCB through metal plate and into case with M3 plastite or tap m3 then use bolts.

title: Star Trek Giant Minifigs: Spock RIP! - By BlackBanshee

description.text: As news breaks about Leonard Nimoy, print your own to remember him by. Files taken from Blackbanshee and located here for easy spock finding in one place. I have done nothing to these files and they are all BlackBanshees http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:328296

Common print files for all four characters: STL file "Star Trek 3D Badge": Print with yellow on the base, then switch colors to black for the perimeter and center star. Print "Young_Adventurer_Eyes_and_Mouth" in black for most characters. Print McCoy eyes in blue. I had to scale this down a bit for it to fit better on my figure (I printed at 85%). Print "star trek collar" in black. Print "Star_Trek_Chest_2" in the various colors for the characters. Print "Snap_Legs" in black Print "Snap_Hips" in black with support. This didn't work so well for me, so I also include this file split into two files ("Snap_Hips_HALF 1" and "Snap_Hips_HALF 2") which I then glued together. Print "Snap_Arms" in the various character colors Print "Arm_Pins_Fixed" in any color (they are hidden in the assembly). Specific Instructions for Spock: Print STL file "spock hair" For Spock's head, you can choose between the full part "Spock Head UNCUT" (will require printing with support, but this didn't work so well for me). So I also include "Spock Head CUT Top" and "Spock Head CUT Bottom" which you print separately and then glue together. Specific Instructions for Kirk/McCoy/Scotty: Print STL file "standard hair", I printed Kirk's hair in brown, then black for McCoy and Scotty. For the head, you can choose between the full part "Young_Adventurer_Head" (will require printing with support, but this didn't work so well for me). So I also include "Young_Adventurer_Head TOP" and "Young_Adventurer_Head BOTTOM" which you print separately and then glue together. Glue and assemble parts. I had to shave some of the parts with an Exacto knife to get them to fit.
Then boldly go where no man has gone before!

I hope you like it and props to walter for the original model that I used as a source.

title: Luke Skywalkers Lightsaber (Return of the Jedi) - UPDATED: MARK II
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDIT (10/12/15): So I've just come across this other design on tested.com and it looks like this guy has done a way more professional job than me so I'd recommend checking that out first:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/star-wars-lightsaber-complex-version (complex print)
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/star-wars-lightsaber-normal-version (simpler print) This started out as a model I did years ago to recreate a prop I saw being sold online (an accurate one). I wondered what it would take to make it printable on an FDM printer so I set about splitting up the model (for the sake of overhangs) and attaching threads. I've come up with what you see here. Note that I did do a test print but I had warping, the model did the job nicely but the print isn't pretty (not the models fault, but the cold weathers fault...). If you have any questions then feel free to message me. Some notes (UPDATED):
-The curved pieces the blade activation button panel is supposed to slot into did not print in my test print but I think I have now fixed this. If you find this does not print then please do tell me
-I used a flashforge creator to do the test print
-This model is 28cm tall when constructed, 1:1 scale
-The spacing between the male and female threads is 0.3mm
-ABS is recommended for the sake of the threads, as is more than 1 shell
-That circular unthreaded piece sits between two pieces which screw into each other
-For reference the build size box you see in the two complete assembly model pictures is of a flashforge creators maximum build size
-The smaller parts may need to be glued together, they are too small (for me at least) to do proper detail with as they are Plans for a future iteration of this:
-Blade fittings - someone requested a model where you could fit on blades you can buy from places, I plan to look into this and add it in
-Smaller parts that actually clip into each other and onto the blade (they STILL don't which is proving tricky...)
-Better topology around the square holes (as the loops I had to put in added sharpness where I didn't want it). This is barely noticeable and very low priority though
-Dissassembly options for electronic inserts (light lights!)

• Print it in ABS, 3 shells preferably and some infill so things don't snap (the more the better but it obviously adds a lot of time). You could do it hollow if you print with interior supports (with replicatorG this is just the 'full supports' option)
  • Screw it all into itself using a picture as a guide but be careful as you do this so it does not snap
    • Note: Do not print this in PLA without a fair bit of infill (although you 'may' be okay with slow print speeds), the threads do not like it...

comments.text: In regards to the Obi-Wan lightsaber from Tested. It is a very cool assembly. But it is actually overly complex. It is not the strongest way of doing it, and not ideal for fdm. Dont get me wrong the engineering is very impressive, but the design is more suited for metal construction than plastic. As someone who has printed 5 sabers I think you're Luke model is a better design for desktop printing than the Obi-Wan model fetured on Tested.

Just a little box I needed

In this day and age, collecting change is an annoying inevitability which really is not worth our time. Unless that is, we have an             organization system to simplify our coin storage and retrieval. This quarter dispenser is all one needs to eliminate the need for a clunky change jar.

I needed somewhere to put my Surface Pen, so I made a place to put it. I'm very new to 3D printing so the whole thing is kind of a joke about learning all the ins-and-outs. I made it in Tinkercad, practicing my geometry.  
It's perfectly obvious that the stand can STAND on it's own, it builds perfectly at a 45 degree angle, but I added some ridiculously overworked hand-made cubes at weird angles to "support" it (which are completely unnecessary and much harder to print) - like a little kid trying to prove something is 3D printed. Then it turned out to be actually very good at it's job! The ring is in just the right place to not interfere with any pen-clips, the pen can't slide out, you can make it pretty heavy if you infill it, and I actually like how it looks.  
It holds a pen, stylus, or tablet-type pen. It'll hold one of those golden expensive-people pens, if it's not too huge, and you can just scale it up anyways. I think you'd have to scale for a regular sized Sharpie, but it just might fit (I can't find one).  
I printed in Red PLA at medium quality .2 mm, no rafts or supports, and the cubes turn out a little messier or more perfect in different variations depending on the conditions. Usually they print darn well! A tiny glop can make an entire cube messy though. It's fun learning.  
My first "Thing", and I welcome any comments or changes. I put up the stand also just plain, because I think it's a good basic stand I haven't seen before. Anyone is welcome to mess with it! :)

The pictures were printed in PLA on a Makerbot 5th Gen. Medium Quality, .2mm layers, infill anything you like to make it heavier or not, no rafts or supports needed. Takes my printer about 2:30 I think.  
I think the first cube sticking out of the bottom solid with 3 arms is what makes it stable enough to print pretty neatly (just get your build plate right and no wind drafts etc.)  It's really testing my printer to build those silly cubes.  
Any suggestions welcome!

description.text: this is a prototype connector design for assembling geodesic domes and spheres. rather than using preset strut angles, it uses a flexible ball joint strut connection that allows the structure to adapt to a variety of configurations. therefore, all that's required to build a dome of any scale or frequency is the proper strut length calculations, available from: http://simplydifferently.org or http://desertdomes.com the design is based off of william adams' yazzo disc joint openscad script, modified to include a shape language of hexagons and pentagons for the six- and five-way connector types. the strut caps used in this prototype should fit 3/8" diameter dowels (but they might not) update 3/16 â€” added strutcap.scad. other code forthcoming.

depending on your application, print out the proper number of hexagonal and pentagonal connectors. for each strut required, you'll need two strut caps that will attach to either end of the dowel. then, simply snap the ball-end of the strut cap into the receptacles on the connector to build your desired space frame.

comments.text: Do you have more photos of that assembled dome?  That's really great.  How did it hold up?  No buckling of the joints under the stresses?
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: After considering this design somewhat, and thinking about why the balls would not fit, I have the following observation.  A fundamental feature of the original design was in the flexibility of the material between the balls.  There was enough give such that the first balls goes in fairly easily, and by the last ball, it's extremely hard to get the ball into the slot.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: agreed, flexibility is tops when you're dealing with so many joints. getting the tolerances correct was difficult; especially across different 'bots and plastics. i wonder about adding slits between the holes on the disc or cutting a + shape into the ball itself would help. need to try that out!

description.text:
This simple angled Mobius Camera Mount was designed to place the HD recording camera on an angle, so when flying forward it is not recording looking at the ground. There are four versions: 12.5° Version: Good for an average flyier, if you don't get crazy crazy. 15° Version: You sir, have some guts. Print this if you fly like a champ! MobiusMountV1: Angled at 12.5° without a center hole
MobiusMountV2: Angled at 12.5° with a center hole
MobiusMountV1.15: Angled at 15° without a center hole
MobiusMountV2.15: Angled at 15° with a center hole MobiusMountV1: This model is for the people that want to mount using double sided tape, or something alike. NOTE: I have experienced the mount (and camera) departing from the quad copter after a hard crash. MobiusMountV2: This model is for the people that want to mount using wrap around velcro, through the middle, or a zip tie. Maybe using both (zip tie to grip the mount onto the quadcopter and using double sided tape to help with "Jello-ing" would be a good option to secure the mount onto the quad.

MobiusMountV1: This model is for the people that want to mount using double sided tape, or something alike. NOTE: I have experienced the mount (and camera) departing from the quad copter after a hard crash. I printed mine at 100% infill, its a simple print so it is up to you.  
MobiusMountV2: This model is for the people that want to mount using wrap around velcro, through the middle, or a zip tie. Maybe using both (zip tie to grip the mount onto the quadcopter and using double sided tape to help with "Jello-ing" would be a good option to secure the mount onto the quad. When you print, make sure to print it where there are no overhangs.

I slide these rings onto the battery contacts of lipos with HXT-4mm connectors after charging them. Only charged batteries have charge markers. The rings block the contacts and are removed before the batteries are used so it is impossible to forget to remove the charge markers. This is a simple system for keeping track of which batteries need to be charged after a trip to the field. I am thinking of printing rings in a different color and use these to mark storage charged batteries. I have not started doing so yet, but it seems like a good idea. The markers are both quick and easy to print. The rings in the images are printed with 0.3 layer height. I have made another variant for XT60 connectors than can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:700056 And yet another for JST connectors that can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:701473
Guide is mounted on the Z axis profile to guide the filament while printing

author: CBiker

title: Sandmation, Acrobat
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: "Sandmation, Acrobat" is a "sand animated" acrobat. As is "Sandmation, Teeter Totter", this is a 3D printed version of an animated toy available for children almost a hundred years ago. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PFbVLWH_Ph4&feature=youtu.be. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill). UPDATE: Added "Hopper, 8mm by 8mm.stl". This rotates the acrobat much faster.

Parts I purchased:  
1) Very fine colored sand (hobby, craft store, Amazon).  
Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print and assemble all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp". After printing, remove the hold down tabs.  Note there are two hoppers:  "Hopper.stl", and "Hopper, 8mm by 8mm.stl".  In the original video, I used "Hopper.stl", but if you wish your acrobat to spin faster, use "Hopper, 8mm by 8mm.stl".   
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp".  
Comment if you have questions.

This is a case for this instructable:
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-make-a-solar-iPodiPhone-charger-aka-Might/ I didn't like putting it in an altoid case and having to stick the solar panel on the outside, so designed a simple case to hold everything. The inner walls are to keep things from sliding around, if you dont want to glue stuff down. Lid hooks on solar panel and slides down, which you can then screw in. Use any screw you feel fits, I just made the holes on for the lid to act as lead holes for drilling out better holes. To fit everything:
Make sure to get rid of alot of the extra solar panel cable, all that extra cable wont fit in the box. Put in the electronics first, then battery on top, then slide the solar panel over top. (may need to be jiggle around to get everything to sit snug). NOTE:
The lid has built in support for the small flaps that slide into the top of the box. Should be able to snip and twist off, some sanding may be needed. UPDATE(3/15/2011):
More pictures added for assembly help.

Print. UPDATE (3/15/2011):
To Assemble:
Put in the two components, lay the battery on top, then slide the solar panel over top.
To get the lid on, first hook the edge of the solar panel into groove on lid, then slide lid hooks into box. Screw in to finish. Either use support for back hole and then clean
Or use the model with built in support.

comments.text: Sorry. I'm new to this, and didn't quite understand the "heritage"? Of this piece and that it was so popular! I feel like I'm stepping on peoples' toes when I don't attribute correctly. I was just trying to make a barrel of octopuses for my best friend's 40th birthday. But staring at this octopus and messing with the mesh to make the arms taller and the curls shorter, and then printing like 5 times.. I think I've gone mad thinking about octopuses :) I genuinely came to "rocktopus" from shamrock, but it's all the funnier that it was done first! Would you be ok if I mixed your Spock with my taller arms and less spiraled octopus for the intent of "barrel of octopuses game"? I think it would be a funny barrel if there were some spocktopuses and rocktopuses, but I'd also like them to have the taller arms that I made. It's just more sturdy, without losing the delicate look of the top down view. :)

author: michiexile

description.text:
The audio jack on my computer is blocked (pro tip: don't use cheap audio cables and have them break in your computer) and I'm stuck using this for the time being. It's a USB audio output device i bought off of amazon for about $20 so I would at least get sound from my computer.
It protrudes a lot and is very prone to bending especially when it's not on a flat surface. And since it's a cheap piece of junk it's very close to breaking, so I made this to secure it to my computer a bit more. This model was designed was designed to adapt to my macbook pro.

description.text:
Just another Wade-style extruder.
It's rotated by 90 degrees and uses a 3:1 GT2 belt drive. The belt should have about 78 teeth, but can vary by a small amount.

BOM:
(1x) Hobbed Bolt (with washers and nuts)
(1x) NEMA17 Motor
(1x) 20t GT2 Pulley
(1x) 78t GT2 Belt
(2x) 608 Bearing
(1x) 688 Bearing
(1x) 8x18mm smooth rod or threaded rod
(2x) M4x50
(2x) M4x20
(1x) M3x30
(3x) M3x10
(4x) M4 Hex Nut

title: Button circuit boards to use with PiSP

description.text:
Circuit boards for the buttons used in the PiSP. NOTE: NOT FINISHED.
Todo:
  • Need to create the boards for shoulder buttons.
  • Create vias and header pads for the shoulder buttons.
  • Create Start/Select board.
    • This is just an early draft. Any suggestions to improve this is welcome...
  • If the dimensions are not correct... write a comment!
  • If it's not fitting correctly, write a comment! :)
  • If the vias are connected to the buttons incorrectly.... well, you get the idea.
    • If nothing is being written, I'm going to assume that it's all hunky dory.

If you create this board the way I'm doing it, you will need the following:
  • Laser printer
  • Glossy paper (catalog/magazine cover paper is good)
  • Copper clad board
  • Lamination machine (or hand iron if you're daring)
  • Etchant (Ferric Chloride or Cupric Chloride)
  • Drill press
  • Hacksaw (or whatever tool you like to use to cut circuit boards)
  • Sink
    • The process is as follows:
  • Take the PDFs and print it onto a catalog cover (or other glossy paper that will release toner easily)
  • Tape the print to a circuit board that's cut to the appropriate size.
  • Transfer the print via heat. I suggest running it through a laminator 12 or so times.
  • Dunk in water and after soaking through, rub away the wet paper.
  • Place the circuit board in etchant, such as ferric chloride.
  • Clean the board and remove carbon masking with Acetone or rubbing alcohol.
  • Drill out the copper pads and screw points.
  • Solder the components and wires as needed.
  • Install into the PiSP.

First off some warnings.  
Because of the limited space on the D5S do not use this mount with the dial indicator in place under power. If you were to home the printer the dial indicator would hit before the Y limit switch is tripped.  
I use this powered off moving the head SLOWLY as not to generate feedback from the motor to the board avoiding damage.  
Use this at your own risk.  
The mount is designed to fit on the head where the second fan mount holes are.  
A typical 8mm stem dial gauge will fit fine.  
There are 2 versions available.  
Thumbscrew version is designed for a typical computer thumbscrew to be used for the clamping and the thumbscrew screws into a brass motherboard standoff which I cut the thread off and filed smooth.  
Simple version is designed for an M3 or equivalent bolt to be used.  
The choice is yours.

I printed this on my Wanhao D5S Mini with the following settings 50% infill
2 outer shells of 0.4mm
No supports
0.2mm Layer Height Simplify3d custom settings Time to print 32 mins

description.text:
Simple. Easy to custom. Quick to print.
Customise and Create a Bone Tag for your dog!

Original File size is: 50 mm x 25mm x 5mm
And I model it in Rhinoceros for Mac (btw it's free) 1) If you only download and print the .stl file, you can be creative and just print a label and put it on the dog tag. 2) You can download the .3dm file and customize it.
Just type your dog's name with solids and join it with the upper surface.
What I did: Solid + Text + boolean union.

Accessory caddy attaches to an Ayoue 968A+ soldering iron holder using the factory mounting holes. Has a 20mm syringe holder, 10mm tool/tip holders, and a deep well pocket for holding screwdrivers, etc.

Y axis Belts Holder for Makerfarm I3v . i didn't like how the Y belt is attached to the bed with the "zip ties" method provided in the build instruction manual . i wanted to design a simpler and secure way to align the belt . i found this method improves alignment and holds the belt in place without using zip ties. Also not backlash. For installation you will need : 1) Stock M3 Long screw and lock nut.
2) 4- M3x10 or 12 mm
3) 4 M3 nuts

remixed_from.author: jdacal
remixed_from.title: Wall Storage for Wacom Pro Medium Tablet

title: Wall Storage for Wacom Pro Medium Tablet Ver 2.0

description.text: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:702153 NOTE: These mounts are for the Wacom Intuos Pro Tablets. Since initially posting I found that the small, medium and large tablets all are 0.5" thick. So this should work for all the Intuos Pro tablets. Specifically models PTH-451, PTH-651, PTH-651/S, PTH-851 This is a re-mix of my original one. Added some curves to make it more visually pleasing. Ignore the quality of the print in the photos. I printed these at warp speed! I drew this up for my Wacom tablet to open up space on my desk while not in use. Mounts with standard plastic wall anchors. The holder for the stylus is built into the right bracket. You can still connect the charger to it if needed, the charger receptacle is not covered by the wall brackets. If you don't own a 3D printer and would like to purchase, search for these on eBay.
